message.content:
cs.AI, cs.LG, cs.RO, cs.SY, cs.CV. 

The paper deals with the problem of learning to act in a domain where the agent has prior knowledge of the class of tasks in the form of a library of policies that were learnt from sample task instances during an offline training phase. This suggests that the paper is likely to belong to the sub-category of Artificial Intelligence (cs.AI), which deals with the study of intelligent agents and their environments. The paper also presents an algorithm for efficiently responding to a novel task instance by reusing a policy from the library of existing policies, which involves making decisions based on observed 'signals' that correlate to policy performance. This suggests that the paper may also belong to the sub-category of Machine Learning (cs.LG), which deals with the study of algorithms that can learn from and make predictions on data. The paper also deals with the problem of rapid convergence in short-duration episodic tasks, which suggests that it may belong to the sub-category of Robotics (cs.RO), which deals with the study of robots and their interactions with the environment. The paper also presents a model of expected performance of the policy library on their corresponding task instances, which suggests that it may belong to the sub-category of Systems and Control (cs.SY), which deals with the study of systems and their control. Finally, the paper may also belong to the sub-category of Computer Vision and Pattern Recognition (cs.CV), which deals with the study of algorithms
